pages.title: Planning
pages.quote: There is a good deal of evidence that learning is enhanced when teachers pay attention to the knowledge and beliefs that learners bring to a learning task, use this knowledge as a starting point for new instruction, and monitor students' changing conceptions as instruction proceeds.
pages.citation:
National Research Council (1999).
How People Learn: Brain, Mind, Experience, and School.
Bransford, J., Brown, A., and Cocking, R. (eds.).
Washington, D.C.: National Academy of Sciences Press.
pages.more: Planning in a classroom ecosystem helps teachers create a curriculum that is both goal oriented and responsive to children's interests and learning needs. Maintaining a balance between achieving learning goals and leaving room for children's thoughts and ideas requires formal, flexible and project planning. When we include children in the planning process we honor their capabilities and potential and help create an environment that optimizes learning.

pages.title: Formal Planning
pages.definition: Formal planning begins before the school year starts and continues throughout the year. Through formal planning teachers examine state and national science education standards and identify the big ideas and concepts they will address with children.
pages.benefits: The big ideas and concepts in science serve as a guide to help create the physical classroom space and plan learning experiences that will spark children's curiosity and prompt inquiry.
pages.examples: With the National Science Education Standards as their foundation, teachers decide on the big ideas, concepts and supporting concepts they will use to guide their science instruction. For example, a big idea is "consistency and change"; a concept is "matter comes in different forms"; a supporting concept is "how temperature affects the different states of matter." On a weekly basis teachers plan experiences around these ideas and concepts. These might include conducting experiments with liquids, solids and gases; collecting and sorting materials; and using the senses to observe and record findings.

video.title: Lunchtime Planning

planningPoints.text: All the teachers from the K-1 grade level meet to plan experiences that will help children acquire knowledge of the concepts and big ideas. Allocating time for grade-level meetings requires the support of administrators.
Although one teacher starts the conversation, as it goes along everyone contributes different ideas.
Meeting as a group allows the teachers to share ideas. After their discussion, they will implement the ideas in ways that are suited to their students.

setupPoints.text: Teachers consider which materials and resources will be best suited to setting up firsthand experiences that illustrate the concepts.
A teacher suggests using a large Arrowhead water bottle because it is common to all the classrooms and is heavy enough to present a challenge for the children when they try to move it.
Using the playground equipment for experiences with force and motion extends the learning environment and helps children make connections between the concepts and the world around them.

culturePoints.text: The teachers plan experiences that the children will share, which helps ensure everyone has background knowledge of the concepts and provides context for their discussions.

Notice that the teacher anticipates the children will realize the easiest way to move the water bottle will be to roll it. She talks about honoring their response and then asking them to try another way.

exPoints.text: K-1 teachers discuss what firsthand experiences to provide for the students to demonstrate different kinds of forces.
As the teachers consider different possibilities for experiences for the children, they anticipate how the children will react and what they will think while they are having the experiences.
Asking children to move one of the large Arrowhead water bottles in their classroom offers a hands-on task that can inspire "how" and "why" questions and lead to further exploration.
Once the teachers have given the children some background knowledge on force and motion, they will take the children to the playground for firsthand experiences to reinforce the concept.

repPoints.text: Linking concepts and experiences in their planning discussions will help the teachers later as they assess the children's representations.
The experiences the teachers are planning will be followed by discussion, where children will have the opportunity to orally represent their understanding of the concepts.

video.description: All the K-1 teachers meet to discuss experiences students will need to acquire an understanding of different forces (i.e. gravity, friction, push, pull, etc.) and how these forces cause motion.
video.standards:
The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background.
  2. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time.
  3. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull.
  4. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move.
  5. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

enrich.intro: Before developing Formal Planning, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It is seen as a continual process
It begins with teachers identifying the concepts and big ideas
list.more: After looking at state and national science education standards, teachers discuss and record the big ideas and concepts they will teach throughout the year. To prevent jumping from unit to unit and to help facilitate in-depth learning, teachers also spend time planning how to connect these concepts and big ideas.

list.text: It provides teachers with a framework of concepts and big ideas
list.more: Days are set aside either before the school year begins or within the first month of school to write up the science curriculum based on state and national science education standards. Teachers begin by identifying the concepts and big ideas and then plan learning experiences around them. They also determine how students will show what they know.

challenges.theText:
My days are already so full, how can I fit in time to plan with other teachers?
It is often necessary to look for creative ways to make time for planning. You might turn a weekly lunchtime into a potluck gathering where a group of teachers share a meal and discuss the curriculum. You might schedule PE or extracurricular activities at the same time as your teaching partner and use that time to meet. Some teachers meet while classroom aides are supervising children outside. Others fit in brief 15-minute discussions on several different days each week.
Too often in schools we devote more time to discussing day-to-day nuts and bolts than we do planning curriculum goals. Trading some of the time ordinarily spent on procedures and using it instead for discussions of big ideas and concepts helps shift the focus to children's learning.
How can teachers cover everything in the curriculum if they use this approach?
The classroom-ecosystem approach stresses depth over breadth. Therefore you should work in the beginning of the year to carefully select the areas you will spend more time on than others. Examine the curriculum and the science education standards and try to determine which concepts and big ideas will be most meaningful for children. Work with other teachers to eliminate the redundancies that rarely deepen understanding.
When teachers feel pressed to cover everything in the standards, the result is a watered down or disconnected program. If you approach the curriculum in terms of big ideas and concepts rather than topics and themes or isolated facts, you'll be better able to help children make connections and gain in-depth knowledge.
Should a teacher ever say "no" to an idea or investigation that emerges from the student/s?
Yes. A teacher's response to a student's idea or investigation should depend on his or her learning goal for the students. What might they learn from the idea? Does it fit with the science concepts and big ideas? Are there cost or safety concerns that might weigh against implementing this particular idea or investigation?
The fact that students are motivated to come up with ideas and ask questions indicates that the teacher is making science relevant and exciting. One way to determine whether ideas or investigations should be pursued is to ask which of the learning goals they will achieve.
How much do teachers need to know about science to teach this way?
The stronger the teacher's knowledge of the content area the better he or she can help children build their own understanding. A strong knowledge base can also help teachers be sure of where they want to lead children in terms of the learning goals.
To increase their knowledge, teachers can read books, work with colleagues, use teacher guides or carefully selected internet sites, ask experts to come to the classroom, or attend professional development seminars.
Teachers who use the classroom-ecosystem approach need to see themselves as learners with the children, but they also must stay one step ahead, keeping in mind the concepts. Still, that doesn't mean they need to know it all. In the course of investigations children will come up with challenging questions. Teachers must know where to look for information and be willing to take the time to find it. A very important part of the classroom-ecosystem approach is this dynamic of constant learning on the part of both the teacher and the child.

pages.title: Flexible Planning
pages.definition: Flexible planning involves teachers actively listening to children's ideas and including those ideas in the learning experiences. The teacher's challenge is to evaluate the ideas as they come up and decide how or if they fit into the curriculum.
pages.benefits: Seeing their ideas come to life empowers children and gives them incentive to be active participants in their learning environment.
pages.examples: During an experiment with liquids and gases, a child asks how long it would take for a liquid, poured onto the surface of the playground, to become a gas. Although it had not been part of the plan for the day, the teacher uses the "teachable moment" to conduct this experiment with the students.

video.title: Potential Potential Potential

planningPoints.text: Upon realizing a common misconception in their students' understanding of kinetic and potential energy, the teachers take time to review the concepts.
Next the teachers gather the students to address the confusion and clarify the concepts. The teachers have cleared class time for this essential discussion.

At the end of the discussion, one child noted that the transformation of energy is similar to when he and his friends run up and down a hill near the school. The teachers capitalize on the student's insight and take the class to the hill for an impromptu experience that helps reinforce the concepts.

setupPoints.text: The rug area provides a space where the teacher can gather the whole class to clarify the concepts. Here she is able to observe children's reactions and check in that everyone is getting the information.
Taking the children to a grassy hill near the school extends the learning space beyond the classroom.
Being flexible in her planning allows the teacher to pick up on a student's suggestion and results in using a space that is especially well suited to exploring the concepts.

culturePoints.text: In an effective Classroom-Ecosystem, teachers see themselves as continual learners. By consulting with a member of the classroom community who is more expert in physics, the teachers enhance their knowledge and are better able to help the children understand physics.

When teachers and children are constructing knowledge together, it is sometimes necessary to change the plan for the day. Here the teacher has postponed a planned experience so the class can gather for a discussion to clarify the concepts.
Providing opportunities for children to connect the concepts to familiar activities helps make the concepts more meaningful.

exPoints.text: As the teacher speaks, she refers to a diagram of a roller coaster, which she labels. Looking at the diagram is a thirdhand experience for the children, giving them a visual representation of abstract concepts.

As part of their firsthand experiences related to the concepts, the class visited a local amusement park. Recalling their experiences riding roller coasters helps the children make sense of the diagram.
Following a student's suggestion, the teachers take the children to a nearby hill so that they can personally experience the transformation of energy in their bodies as they run up and down.

repPoints.text: The teacher and student refer to the teacher's 2-D representation of a roller coaster as they discuss the concepts.

At the end of the classroom discussion the teacher took the children outside to the 3-D representation of a roller coaster that they had made. She had them identify the sections of the representation where kinetic and potential energy are used.

The teacher requires the children to use formal academic language to describe the movement of matter--potential and kinetic energy--as they run up and down the hill. This reinforces the concepts through two kinds of representation--oral and kinesthetic.

video.description: In the sequence before this video begins, students pointed out areas of potential and kinetic energy on the model roller coaster outside their classroom, and teachers realized there were misunderstandings regarding the concepts (for more on this, see the Example Video for Teacher-Student Culture). Taking advantage of a teachable moment, teachers decided to re-introduce the concepts to clear up the misconceptions. Before the concepts are presented again to the students, however, the teachers want to make sure their own understanding is correct, and so they consult with a physics expert.
video.concept: Energy changes from one form to another
video.standards:
Energy and matter have multiple forms and can be changed from one form to another. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know sources of stored energy take many different forms, such as food, fuel, and batteries.
  2. Students know machines and living things convert stored energy to motion and heat.
  3. Students know energy can be carried from one place to another by waves, such as water waves and sound waves, by electric current, and by moving objects.

enrich.intro: Before developing Formal Planning, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: Children have many opportunities to discuss ideas and concepts
Teachers listen to children's ideas
list.more: Here the teacher asks children to predict the possible outcomes when several different liquids are mixed together. It is in these kinds of discussions that new ideas emerge, which can often change the course of the lesson.

list.text: Teachers incorporate children's ideas into the curriculum
Teachers listen to children's ideas
list.more: Classroom teachers share students' drawings and clay representations of the characteristics of a solid, such as bumpy, pointy, and round. This is followed by a discussion among teachers from the whole grade level to plan next steps.

My days are already so full, how can I fit in time to plan with other teachers?
It is often necessary to look for creative ways to make time for planning. You might turn a weekly lunchtime into a potluck gathering where a group of teachers share a meal and discuss the curriculum. You might schedule PE or extracurricular activities at the same time as your teaching partner and use that time to meet. Some teachers meet while classroom aides are supervising children outside. Others fit in brief 15-minute discussions on several different days each week.

pages.title: Project Planning
pages.definition: Projects are long-term investigations that can last up to several months. They arise from an interest or need the children express and are directly related to the concepts or big ideas that have been presented in the classroom. Planning for a project involves teachers deciding what materials and resources will be needed to implement the children's ideas.
pages.benefits: Project planning helps assure that long-term investigations address the big ideas and concepts and offer children an opportunity to apply their learning in a meaningful way.
pages.examples: During a discussion about how simple machines make work easier, a small group of children suggests building a roller coaster that sends messages back and forth between adjoining classrooms. The teacher recognizes this as an opportunity for children to apply their knowledge of physical science concepts. For several months, children and adults work two mornings a week to design, construct and revise the message sending rollercoaster.

video.title: The Project

planningPoints.text: Many times project ideas generate from the children through conversation and discussion. Other times, teachers ask the students thought-provoking questions that will stimulate ideas for a long-term project.
Teachers discuss the main concept that will be reinforced for the students through the project.

setupPoints.text: The teacher is thinking about using different areas inside and outside the classroom for the project. Depending on what the children decide, the areas will be modified to fit the project design.
After the teachers talk to the children about what they will build, they will do further project planning to determine what resources they need to implement the project.

culturePoints.text: Asking children to contribute their ideas to the project design helps them to be more invested in the work and more likely to develop a deep understanding of the concepts.
Focusing the project on children's play or work helps make the concepts less abstract and encourages the children to make connections between science and their everyday lives.
All the children will contribute to the classroom project. This provides a natural way to help them develop collaborative skills.

exPoints.text: The teacher is thinking about how to design experiences around the project that would integrate other curricular areas.
Planning for this long-term project comes after children have had many experiences that introduced and reinforced the concepts.

repPoints.text: Oftentimes, teachers choose how students will represent their understanding of a concept or big idea. However, there are times when teachers ask students to choose how they want to demonstrate their knowledge. Student choice is a significant part of the process in long-term projects.
The process of designing and building the project will provide many opportunities for teachers to assess children's understanding of the concepts.
Earlier in the year, children designed simple toys as 3-D representations of the concept that simple machines make work easier.

video.description: K-1 teachers from adjoining classrooms meet to discuss possibilities for a long-term project through which students will demonstrate their understanding of the concepts.
video.standards:
The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull.
  2. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move.
  3. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

enrich.intro: Before developing Formal Planning, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It uses children's interests as a guide
list.moreIntro: Children's ideas for projects arise from their experiences. The idea for building a message sending roller coaster came about after children had many experiences with force and motion, kinetic and potential energy, and simple machines.
list.more: After learning that simple machines make work easier, children wanted to create a machine of their own that could send messages between two classrooms. A field trip to LEGOLAND gave them ideas about how to build it - they observed roller coasters, made sketches and brainstormed ideas.
list.moreTwo: As the project emerged, children's discussions became part of the planning process. In both formal and informal discussions the teachers asked, what are the children's interests? The more defined the project became, the more it was a focus in meetings and in the classrooms.

list.text: It uses the concepts and big ideas to provide direction
list.more: Although projects arise from children's ideas, teachers should refer to the big ideas and concepts to provide structure and to ensure that the project work supports the learning goals. The work done in Formal Planning serves as a guide.

challenges.theText:
My days are already so full, how can I fit in time to plan with other teachers?
It is often necessary to look for creative ways to make time for planning. You might turn a weekly lunchtime into a potluck gathering where a group of teachers share a meal and discuss the curriculum. You might schedule PE or extracurricular activities at the same time as your teaching partner and use that time to meet. Some teachers meet while classroom aides are supervising children outside. Others fit in brief 15-minute discussions on several different days each week.

Teachers must know where to look for information and be willing to take the time to find it. A very important part of the classroom-ecosystem approach is this dynamic of constant learning on the part of both the teacher and the child.

pages.title: Setup
pages.quote: Organization of space, classroom displays and the resources available to children convey messages about the relationship between teaching and learning, the image of the child held by the teacher and the expectations for teaching and learning within that setting.
pages.citation:
Edwards, C., Gandini, L., and Forman, G. (1998).
The hundred languages of children: The Reggio Emelia approach.
Greenwich, CT: Ablex.
pages.more: To support in-depth learning, the classroom must be a safe and inviting place for children to ask questions, experiment and take thoughtful risks. All aspects of the classroom setup -space, display and resources- must work together to promote these qualities.

pages.title: Space Setup
pages.definition:
The organization of the physical space in the classroom should be flexible in order to adapt and respond to the different needs of children and convey a sense of well-being to both children and parents.

The classroom space should also support the varied ways that children learn and construct knowledge - by posing questions, generating information from multiple resources, and communicating information to others. To do this, classrooms should include spaces for quiet, reflective work; individual or cooperative work; whole-group or small-group learning; and messy escapades.
pages.benefits: Giving children opportunities to work in a variety of ways and encouraging frequent discussion helps ideas to emerge and connections to be made. Working cooperatively and with different kinds of learners, children have opportunities to communicate their thinking, listen to others, and give and receive feedback about their work from their peers. Working individually helps children focus on the task at hand and make independent decisions.
pages.examples: In a small group, students negotiate how to design two inclined planes, one with a lot of friction, and one with very little. They record their ideas and then bring them to the whole classroom community to gather further suggestions.

video.title: Classroom Space

planningPoints.text: With a variety of spatial configurations, children can work on different aspects of a collaborative project simultaneously. In planning a project, it is important to think ahead about different ways the space--both inside and outside the classroom--can support the project.

Setting up the classroom to support a variety of activities requires formal planning.  However, the more flexible the setup, the more effective it will be in adapting and responding to the needs of children and the ways in which they learn.

setupPoints.text: The strategic arrangement of cabinets and bookcases provides a space for children's imaginary play, a key component of young children's learning.
The positioning of students' large-scale creations (such as the blue Totem Pole) can help divide the classroom space and also provides a display of children's work.
A cozy space for reading (the sofa and coffee table seen here) helps make the classroom more appealing and bridges the transition from home to school.

A large area rug is used for whole-group learning and class discussions. It also offers a space for children to spread out while working independently. Tables and chairs (in the background on the left) provide an area for small groups to work together.
Looking at a bird's-eye view of the learning environment you just watched may help you understand how space can be arranged effectively to maximize the learning potential of your classroom.
To see a full-resolution version of this floorplan, go to the main CEE site, under Resources > Classroom Setup > Classroom Space Floorplan.

culturePoints.text: Areas designed for small groups encourage student interactions and the development of positive social skills.  This helps create a classroom culture where children feel comfortable exchanging ideas.
By moving about the room and checking in with children, the teacher helps them develop independence while also fostering a culture of respect and responsibility.
Providing children with a comfortable, inviting environment lets them know that they are valued and encourages their cooperative participation in the learning community.

exPoints.text: Including lots of books and comfortable reading spaces in the classroom setup encourages children to explore reading materials that support their firsthand and secondhand experiences.
Classrooms should be arranged so that relevant reading materials are readily accessible to children.
A large area rug provides a comfortable space for children to share a secondhand experience such as watching a video.
Incorporating computers into the classroom space, when possible, helps facilitate children's access to secondhand experiences, such as looking at photos or websites chosen by the teacher.

repPoints.text: Children represent their understanding of concepts through dramatic play.  Designating space for this kind of learning encourages children's imaginations and allows teachers to assess understanding.
Children's 3-D representation of a totem pole positioned in the classroom provides a reminder of the process and physical principles of construction, such as gravity, weight and balance.

A large clear space provides an area for kinesthetic representation. It also offers a gathering space for oral representation through discussion. Both provide opportunities for teachers to assess children's understanding.
Incorporating computers into the classroom space, when possible, gives children an additional medium for 2-D representation.

video.description: This video depicts a variety of ways to set up the classroom space for teaching science for young children. Classroom space should be adaptable to support the science content and children's evolving ideas.

enrich.intro: Before developing Space Setup, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It is flexible and adapts to children's needs
It promotes learning and exploration
Children have space to spread out their work
It includes a cozy spot for reading
list.more: Children gather in the library to work in their science journals. Bridging home to school helps create a safe and comfortable learning environment.

list.text: It includes a large rug area for whole-group meetings
list.more: After experimenting with changing liquids to solids and vice versa, teachers gathered students on the rug for a discussion. Having an area where the whole group can gather helps create an environment that promotes discussion and conversation.

list.text: Outdoor space is used whenever possible and appropriate

pages.title: Display Setup
pages.definition: A challenge as educators is to think beyond decorating the classroom and consider how the walls and areas of the room can be used effectively to promote curiosity, inquiry and creativity.
pages.benefits:
Classroom displays of children's on-going and finished work help to stimulate thinking and create dialogue, which in turn lead to new learning.

Displaying documentation of children's thought processes and conversations invites children to edit, revise and give further thought to their work. It gives teachers the opportunity to reflect on their practice. It also provides a way to bring parents into the life of the classroom.
pages.examples: A collaborative project to build a model of a roller coaster is set up in the center of the classroom, where all children can add to it as they develop new knowledge. A painting of a roller coaster is mounted with a simple black border so the details of the child's work stand out.

video.title: Classroom Displays

planningPoints.text: Teachers should look beyond decoration and plan meaningful and functional displays that change along with the classroom.

Coming up with ways to include hands-on displays should be a part of the formal planning of classroom activities.  To correspond with a unit about friction, teachers arranged for classroom families to donate simple materials like sand and scraps of fabric, which were glued to cardboard and displayed on a table to promote student engagement with the concepts.
Teachers planned for their students' 2D and 3D representations of textures to also function as a stimulating wall display.

Plan to take pictures of your students engaged in class projects. These photos can help children and teachers to reflect on their work, and they also help parents be informed members of the classroom community.

setupPoints.text: Classroom displays should be dynamic spaces for student work, as well as for thought-provoking objects that inspire children's thinking.
A table displaying hands-on books and materials becomes an interactive display designed to attract attention and encourage students' engagement.

Look for ways to allow individual and collaborative student projects to be the focus of your classroom display.  Here, students used clay to represent words that describe characteristics of matter.  The individual pieces are arranged to create a visual "chart" that supports students' thinking.
Keeping display boards simple and uncluttered allows children's work to be the focus. A bulletin board covered with busy patterns and colors can detract from the integrity of children's work.

Documenting learning processes and ongoing projects can also be an important part of classroom display.  It encourages students to reflect on their thought processes and past work.  Documentary display also allows teachers to reflect upon their practice.

Allowing ongoing projects to remain a part of the classroom display inspires children to continue thinking about the material throughout the school day. The presence of the rollercoaster on the outside windows of the classroom encourages children to discuss possible additions or changes, and keeps the concepts fresh in their minds.

culturePoints.text: Classroom displays should feature hands-on objects to promote curiosity and engagement. This requires establishing a classroom culture early in the year where students respect classroom property and are trusted to use it appropriately.

Here, student representations are displayed as an informational chart that illustrates the various characteristics of matter. This type of display emphasizes students' work as a source of information, validating their efforts and showing that their contributions to the classroom are valued.

Documentation displays that show photographs of children at work help engage parents in the life of the classroom and make them part of the learning community. Here, parents can see their children engaged in a long-term project, and can follow the evolution of the project step-by-step.

exPoints.text: Including books, posters, and 3D objects in your classroom displays provides children with experiences related to the curricular concepts. Here, teachers have set out simple inclined planes, small blocks of various shapes, and surfaces with different textures for children to explore, providing them with firsthand experiences.

Including reading materials and informational posters in classroom displays offers students thirdhand experiences that enhance their understanding of the concepts and provide background information for firsthand experiences.
Here, the classroom display includes photographs of students exploring the properties of different states of matter through firsthand experiences.

The display tells the story of a "solids hunt", where students went exploring outside and brought back a variety of items with different characteristics. They then categorized the items and wrote descriptions of them.

A student's representation of swings in motion reflects the child's firsthand experience on the playground. Including the representation in the classroom display reinforces for all the students that they experience the physical principles of force and motion every day.

repPoints.text: Student representations of concepts are the cornerstone of classroom display.  Making students' creative work visible in the classroom helps stimulate thinking and reinforces the concepts.
Students' 2-D representations, including labeled diagrams they create to represent their understanding, can be powerful components of a thought-provoking classroom display.

The students' 3D representation of a rollercoaster is mounted on the outside of the classroom, where it can remain while the building process continues. Displaying in-process projects like this one allows children to continually examine their work and add to it as they learn more about the concepts and big ideas.

As part of their unit on motion, the students collaborated on a large-scale mural on canvas, which represents their understanding of the physics at work at a local amusement park. The painting has become a permanent part of the school's hallway display.

video.description: This video depicts a variety of ways that classroom displays support the teaching of science for young children. Classroom displays should adapt to reflect the science content and children's evolving ideas.

enrich.intro: Before developing Display Setup, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It reflects children's culture and ideas
list.more: Integrating social studies with science, teachers had students create their self-portraits using many different kinds of solids.

list.text: It reflects the culture of the school
Displays of children's work include documentation
It includes children's on-going projects
list.more: A roller coaster that sent messages between two adjacent classrooms was built during a three-month period. As children gained more knowledge of the physical science content such as force and motion, kinetic and potential energy, and simple machines, they added new ideas to their project.

list.text: It includes places for the eye to rest and the mind to reflect
It does not rely on pre-packaged materials

challenges.theText:
My days are already so full, how can I fit in time to plan with other teachers?
It is often necessary to look for creative ways to make time for planning. You might turn a weekly lunchtime into a potluck gathering where a group of teachers share a meal and discuss the curriculum. You might schedule PE or extracurricular activities at the same time as your teaching partner and use that time to meet. Some teachers meet while classroom aides are supervising children outside. Others fit in brief 15-minute discussions on several different days each week.
Too often in schools we devote more time to discussing day-to-day nuts and bolts than we do planning curriculum goals. Trading some of the time ordinarily spent on procedures and using it instead for discussions of big ideas and concepts helps shift the focus to children's learning.How can teachers cover everything in the curriculum if they use this approach?
The classroom-ecosystem approach stresses depth over breadth. Therefore you should work in the beginning of the year to carefully select the areas you will spend more time on than others. Examine the curriculum and the science education standards and try to determine which concepts and big ideas will be most meaningful for children. Work with other teachers to eliminate the redundancies that rarely deepen understanding.
When teachers feel pressed to cover everything in the standards, the result is a watered down or disconnected program. If you approach the curriculum in terms of big ideas and concepts rather than topics and themes or isolated facts, you'll be better able to help children make connections and gain in-depth knowledge.Should a teacher ever say "no" to an idea or investigation that emerges from the student's?
Yes. A teacher's response to a student's idea or investigation should depend on his or her learning goal for the students. What might they learn from the idea? Does it fit with the science concepts and big ideas? Are there cost or safety concerns that might weigh against implementing this particular idea or investigation?
The fact that students are motivated to come up with ideas and ask questions indicates that the teacher is making science relevant and exciting. One way to determine whether ideas or investigations should be pursued is to ask which of the learning goals they will achieve.How much do teachers need to know about science to teach this way?
The stronger the teacher's knowledge of the content area the better he or she can help children build their own understanding. A strong knowledge base can also help teachers be sure of where they want to lead children in terms of the learning goals.
To increase their knowledge, teachers can read books, work with colleagues, use teacher guides or carefully selected internet sites, ask experts to come to the classroom, or attend professional development seminars.
Teachers who use the classroom-ecosystem approach need to see themselves as learners with the children, but they also must stay one step ahead, keeping in mind the concepts. Still, that doesn't mean they need to know it all. In the course of investigations children will come up with challenging questions. Teachers must know where to look for information and be willing to take the time to find it. A very important part of the classroom-ecosystem approach is this dynamic of constant learning on the part of both the teacher and the child.

pages.title: Resource Setup
pages.definition: Resources in the classroom should be readily accessible and include objects and materials that attract attention, invite curiosity, inspire discussion, and support a variety of ways of thinking and representing ideas. They should include objects found in nature, recycled materials and interesting or unusual books. There should be materials such as wood, wire, fabric, tiles, and paper of different sizes, shapes, textures and weight. There also should be a variety of art supplies such as charcoal, clay, paints, colored pencils and pastels.
pages.benefits: Resources provide children with the means to express themselves, support their learning process and communicate what they have learned. Offering a variety of interesting resources in a way that is readily accessible to children fosters independence and helps children grow as learners.
pages.examples: To represent the characteristics of a solid, the teacher provides students with a variety of natural materials that can be used to symbolize qualities such as "pointy," "rough," "crunchy" and "shiny."

video.title: Classroom Resources

planningPoints.text: Thinking about what materials children will need in their work is an important part of planning. When planning for a long-term project, teachers should consider asking parents to bring in modest materials and scraps for the children's use.

To support children's understanding of solids, the teacher planned an experience in which she provided a variety of rocks for the children to sort into groups according to characteristics.  She had the rocks waiting on tables for children when they returned from lunch so they could get to work right away.

In formal planning in the beginning of the year, the teacher arranged for every child to have a clipboard for recording observations. The sturdy clipboards can be taken on field trips and reused from year to year.
Teachers can work with their school or local librarian to select reading materials that enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas.

Including resources such as wheels and axles in the dramatic play area helps ensure that even unstructured choice time provides an opportunity to enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas.

setupPoints.text: Resources should include books, art supplies and an assortment of creative materials. To foster independence and creativity, children should be able to access resources when they need them and without assistance.

Grouping supplies in an attractive manner makes them inviting to children. It also inspires children to want to experiment with different media, which in turn enriches their work and provides multiple opportunities for assessment.

Resources are as much a part of the classroom's physical environment as the furniture and display boards.  Their visibility is a constant reminder to children that thinking is an active process, and that ideas should be recorded, experimented with, evaluated and revised.

Book displays should be changed and updated to correspond with the subject matter taught in the classroom. Here, a selection of books about force and motion and simple machines provide information related to the concepts and big ideas.
A small table display provides stimulating, unusual and thought-provoking items that children may explore on their own.

Asking classroom families to bring in modest materials and scraps can be an inexpensive way to support a large-scale project.  Designating a kid-friendly place in the classroom for these varied supplies broadens children's thinking and encourages creativity.

culturePoints.text: Setting up spaces where materials are stored in an attractive and welcoming way encourages pride in the learning environment and inspires children's thinking.
Storing materials so that they are always at hand tells children that they are capable, responsible members of the classroom community and that they have important work to do.

Communicating expectations and setting routines supports a classroom culture where everyone takes responsibility for their surroundings. In turn, children should be trusted to treat classroom property with respect and to work as independently as possible.

exPoints.text: To support children's understanding of solids, the teacher set out materials for a firsthand experience in which children sorted a variety of rocks into groups according to characteristics.

Books about force and motion and simple machines provide thirdhand experiences to enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas. Making reading materials readily available throughout the room encourages children to use books as a resource in their work and to explore science related materials during reading time.

A classroom setup that incorporates resources related to the concepts and big ideas encourages children to seek out firsthand experiences on their own. Observations and information gathered from these experiences can inform classroom discussions.

repPoints.text: Keep in mind that no one medium offers the best means of expression for every child. Offering a wide variety of materials to be used in representation helps children convey their understanding of concepts and big ideas and also can give the teacher a more accurate assessment of children's understanding.
Clipboards are one way to provide a convenient and efficient way for children to record observations. The observations will later inform children's representations of the concepts and big ideas.
Including a selection of nonfiction books amongst other hands-on materials encourages children to see the books as reference tools to be used in creating representations.
Resources for large-scale representations can include a variety of donated materials. Using donated or found materials keeps costs low and inspires children to extend their thinking.

video.description: This video depicts a variety of resources to be used in teaching science for young children. A variety of adaptable resources should be offered to support the science content and children's evolving ideas.

enrich.intro: Before developing Resource Setup, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It includes a variety of materials
list.more: Natural materials like these were offered to children to assist them in representing the different characteristics of a solid. Providing a variety of materials helps give students choices and assures that each child's work will be distinctive and unique.

list.text: Materials are accessible to children
list.more: To show their understanding of a force creating motion, students were asked to create a surface with friction and a surface without. These students independently look for materials that would best represent a bumpy, rough surface.
list.moreTwo: To help students get a better understanding of how simple machines work, a repair shop was set up in the classroom. To their delight the students were able to take apart the machines and see wheels, screws, wedges, inclined planes and levers.

list.text: Materials inspire imagination
Nothing in the room is off limits to children

pages.title: Culture
pages.quote: Visitors to UCLA Lab School are impressed by how articulate students are in describing their own learning processes. That lack of shame in incomplete mastery does not happen by accident. It is a matter of teachers managing the face threat potential of engaging students at the leading edge of their capacity, or in the zone of proximal development.
pages.citation: Adapted from Erickson, F., with Bagrodia, R., Cook-Sather, A., Espinoza, M., Jurow, S., Shultz, J. and Spencer, J. (2007). Students' Experience of School Curriculum: The Everyday Circumstances of Granting and Withholding Assent to Learn. In Connelly, F.M. et al (eds.), The Sage Handbook of Curriculum. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications, Inc., pp. 198-218.
pages.more: An effective classroom ecosystem is one in which teachers and students work together with mutual respect and as active participants in the learning process. Teachers facilitate active learning by providing opportunities for children to work in a variety of social arrangements; by modeling respect for ideas, encouraging questions, and valuing mistakes as part of learning; and by fostering children's independent use of resources to construct knowledge.

pages.title: Experiences
pages.quote: A multiplicity of our five senses, the only avenues into the brain, are activated through firsthand experiences.
pages.citation:
Lowery, L. (1998).
The Biological Basis of Thinking and Learning (Monograph), p. 18
Berkeley, CA: Lawrence Hall of Science.
pages.more: Before children can formulate questions or show what they know, they have to be provided with experiences related to the content. Once children have been provided background knowledge either through firsthand or secondhand experiences, they are ready to work with text, which both uses and deepens prior knowledge. The goal in providing children with a variety of experiences is to help them move from novice to expert in their understanding and their ability to apply their knowledge of the concepts.

pages.title: Representation
pages.quote: Different forms of representation evoke, develop, and refine the modes of thinking that contribute to the cultivation of what is broadly called mind... By no means is thinking limited to what words alone can carry.
pages.citation:
Eisner, E. (December 2003/January 2004).
Preparing for Today and Tomorrow,
Educational Leadership, p. 6
pages.more:
Representation is the means by which students demonstrate and communicate their knowledge of big ideas and concepts both to the teacher and to themselves. Students create representations in a variety of ways, including drawing, writing, graphing, sculpting and movement. This work can be categorized into four key formats--oral/textual, kinesthetic, two-dimensional and three-dimensional--each of which offers unique opportunities for children to deepen their understanding. (See General Guidelines for Choosing a Representational Format)

Deep understanding of a concept includes knowing about its structure, its behavior and its function, or the "what," the "how," and the "why" of the concept. For example, to understand the concept "Simple machines make work easier," students must know what are the different parts of the simple machine (structure), how the simple machine works (behavior) and why it makes work easier (function). One type of representation may help students see the "what" while another may help them see the "how."

Additionally, asking children to create multiple representations of concepts and big ideas helps them to synthesize and build knowledge. Offering opportunities to represent concepts in a variety of ways helps to ensure that children with differences in learning style, previous experiences and background knowledge will be engaged and invested in the learning process. At the same time, representation provides important tools for assessing children's understanding and allows the teacher to make informed decisions about instruction. The result is greater effectiveness in addressing children's individual learning needs, which ultimately helps ensure academic success for every child.
